ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .

The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I was technically registered as an independent study, but this review is for Eric Toensmeier's course Multifunctional Carbon Sequestering Agroforestry, which is what I was taking. This course was in incredibly high demand this semester, as it is the only course on agricultural management at FES, which is a growing interest among students. The course was capped at 12 because of funding for the field trip component. However, because this is such a popular course that fills such a unique niche at FES, there should be more funding for more students to take this course and the associated field trip. This is a chance for FES to respond to student demand in a really straightforward way. There aren't very many practitioners teaching at FES, and the chance to learn from someone who is so active in his field outside of academia was really special. This is one of the most unique, applicable, and exciting courses at FES.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Eric Toensmeier is boundlessly excited about his material. He is also directly engaged with many aspects of the agroforestry community and is driven by endless curiousity, so his information is truly cutting edge.

Provided outstandingly concrete guidance and expertise, genuinely interested and knowledgeable in the area covered by the independent study. Eric is an indispensable and rare resource to all students here at F&ES interested in agroforestry and agriculture.
Toensmeier is exceptionally knowledgeable and enthusiastic about permaculture and agroforestry. It was a delight to attend his class and work with him.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The material became somewhat repetitive by the end of the course. Also, it might be nice to go deeper into the farm enterprise modeling and to compare successful enterprise models with less successful ones, and discuss what makes a good v. bad model.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: For students interested in agricultural management, this course is critically important to learn some ag basics as well as cutting edge innovations.
I'm interested in the intersection between conservation and sustainable development, which makes agroforestry and permaculture particularly interesting to me.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To pursue more applied projects on agriculture outside of course offerings
How could I NOT take this class? Professor Toensmeier is amazing, and the material is something I'm very interested in personally and professionally.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, above and beyond. Super exciting material.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Not everyone can make a 6-9pm class enjoyable and worth going to every week, but Toensmeier certainly did. His enthusiasm for the topic is infectious, and I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in sustainable agriculture, agroforestry, or permaculture.
